description: A small, black-hearted, selfish humanoid that lair in caves, abandoned
mines, despoiled dungeons, and other dismal settings. Individually weak,
goblins gather in large - sometimes overwhelming - numbers. It craves power
and regularly abuses whatever authority it obtains.
A savage raider and pillager with stooped posture, low forehead, and a
piggish face with prominent lower canines that resemble tusks.
Craven reptilian humanoids that worship evil dragons as demigods and serve
them as minions and toadies. It inhabits dragons' lairs when it can but more
commonly infest dungeons, gathering treasures and trinkets to add to their own
tiny hoards.
War horns sound, stones fly from catapults, and the thunder of a thousand
booted feet echoes across the land as hobgoblins march to battle. Across the
borderlands of civilization, settlements and settlers must contend with these
aggressive humanoids, whose thirst for conquest is never satisfied.
It has dark orange or red-orange skin, and hair ranging from dark red-brown to
dark gray. Yellow or dark brown eyes peer out beneath its beetling brows, and
its wide mouth sport sharp and yellowed teeth. The male might have a large blue
or red nose, which symbolizes virility and power among goblinkin. It can live
as long as humans, though their love of warfare and battle means that few do.
Its life is nasty, brutish, and wet. These frog-headed amphibious humanoids
must stay constantly moist, dwelling in rainy forests, marshes, and damp
caves. Always hungry and thoroughly evil, bullywugs overwhelm opponents with
superior numbers when they can, but they flee from serious threats to search
for easier prey.
Arises when animated by dark magic. It heeds the summons of spellcasters who
call them from their stony tombs and ancient battlefields, or rise of their
own accord in places saturated with death and loss, awakened by stirrings of
nycromantic energy or the presence of corrupting evil.
Feral humanoids that attack settlements along the frontiers and borderlands
of civilization without warning, slaughtering its victims and devouring
their flesh.
It is born for battle and mayhem. Surviving by raiding and hunting,
they bully the weak and despise being bossed around, but their love of
carnage means they will fight for powerful masters if bloodshed and treasure
are assured.
It roams the night in packs, driven by an insatiable hunger for humanoid flesh.
These malevolent creatures of elemental earth that resemble grotesque, fiendish
statues. It lurks among masonry and ruins, as still as any stone sculpture, and
delights in the terror it creates when it breaks from its suspended pose, as
well as the pain it inflicts on its victims.
Orcus sometimes infuses a ghoul with a stronger dose of abyssal energy, whereas
ghouls are little more than savage beasts, a ghast is cunning and can inspire a
pack of ghouls to follow its commands.
Monstrous, fire-breathing fiends that take the form of powerful dogs, it is
found on the battlefieldsof Acheron and throughout the Lower Planes. On the
Material Plane, it is most commonly seen in service to devils, fire giants,
and other evil creatures that use them as guard animals and companions.
A fierce predator of the Underdark, it aggressively defends its hunting
grounds. The subterranean caverns where these creatures dwell echo with the
constant clacking and scraping of its hooks as it winds their way up cliffs
and along cavern walls.
The monstrous beast has a head resembling a vulture's and the torso of an
enormous beetle, with an exoskeleton studded by sharp, bony protuberances.
It gains its name from its long, powerfully built arms and legs, which end
in wickedly curved hooked claws.
It resembles an enormous many-legged insect, its long antennae twitching in
response to any movement around it. Its legs end in sharp hooks adapted for
burrowing and grasping its prey, and its powerful mandibles can snap a small
tree in half.
It looks like a hideous hybrid of lizard, bird, and bat, and it is infamous
for its ability to turn flesh to stone. These omnivores have a diet that
consists of berries, nuts, flowers, and small animals such as insects, mice,
and frogs -- things they can swallow whole. They would be no threat to
anything else if not for their fierce and frenzied response to even a hint of
danger. It flies into the face of any threat, squawking and madly beating its
wings as its head darts out to peck. The smallest scratch from its beak can
spell doom as its victim slowly turns to stone from the injury.
A monstrous predator takes its name from its ability to displace light so that
it appears to be several feet away from its actual location. It resembles a
sleek great cat covered in blue-black fur. However, its otherworldly origins
are clear in its six legs and the two tentacles sprouting from its shoulders,
both ending in pads tipped with spiky protrusions. Its eyes glow with an awful
malevolence that persists even in death.
Devious shapeshifters that take on the appearance of other humanoids, it
throws off pursuit or luring victims to their doom with misdirection and
disguise. Few creatures spread fear, suspicion, and deceit better than them.
Found in every land and culture, they can take on the guise of any individual
of any race.
An insidious demon from the Abyss, it is often found serving chaotic evil
spellcasters as counselors and spies. Although it thirsts for victory and
power as other demons do, it is a coward at heart. It typically attacks from
ambush, using its alternate form ability and invisibility to get within reach,
then try to scuttle away.
It scours putrid flesh from carcasses and gobble the slimy bones that remain.
They aggressively attack any creature that tresspasses on their territory or
disturbs their feasting.
A malice incarnate, concentrated into an incorporeal form that seeks to
quench all life. The creature is suffused with negative energy, and its
mere passage through the world leaves nearby plants blackened and withered.
Animals flee from its presence. Even small fires can be extinguished by the
sucking oblivion of the wraith's horrifying existence.
Travelers sometimes find objects that look like pieces of remarkably lifelike
stone carvings of wildlife. Missing parts appear to have been bitten off.
Seasoned explorers regard such relics as warnings, knowing that the basilisk
that created them is likely to be nearby.
Drow transformed into twisted and debased creatures, driven by madness, it
disappears into the Underdark to become hermits and hunters, either wandering
alone or leading packs of giant spiders.
Selfish, dimwitted brutes that hunt, forage, and raid in constant search of
food. It blunders through hills and forests devouring what it can, bullying
smaller creatures into feeding them. Its laziness and dullness would long ago
have spelled their end if not for their formidable size and strength.
A reptilian horror with a crocodilian body and multiple heads on long,
serpentine necks. Although its heads can be severed, it magically regrows them
in short order. A typical specimen has five heads.
At the dawn of time, an evil dragon slew a rival dragon god named Lernaea and
cast its blood across the multiverse. Each drop that fell upon a world spawned
a multi-headed hydra consumed by a hunger as great as the fallen god's hatred.
Great champions are known to test their mettle against these fearsome creatures.
Malevolent, wispy balls of light that haunt lonely places and battlefields,
bound by dark fate or dark magic to feed on fear and despair.
The angry, unfettered spirit of a humanoid that has been prevented from
passing to the afterlife. It no longer possess connections to who or what it
was, yet are condemned to walk the world forever. Some are spawned when dark
magic or the touch of a wraith rips a soul from a living body.
An intelligent serpent that inhabits the ruins of the past, amassing arcane
treasures and knowledge. The first nagas were created as immortal guardians
by a humanoid race long lost to history. When this race died out, the nagas
deemed themselves the rightful inheritors of their masters' treasures and
magical lore. Industrious and driven, nagas occasionally venture out from
their lairs to track down magic items or rare spellbooks.
Nagas never feel the ravages of time or succumb to sickness. Even if it is
struck down, a naga's immortal spirit reforms in a new body in a matter of
days, ready to continue its eternal work.
The most cunning and treacherous of true dragons, it uses misdirection and
trickery to get the upper hand against their enemies. Nasty tempered and
thoroughly evil, they take special pleasure in subverting and corrupting the
good-hearted. Wherever it may roam, it demonstrates an aggression that is
often less about territory than it is about gaining power and wealth with as
little effort as possible.
The most covetous of the true dragons, it tirelessly seeks to increase its
treasure hoards. It is exceptionally vain, even for dragons, and its conceit
is reflected in its proud bearing and its disdain for other creatures.
It remains immortal only as long as it feeds mortal souls to its phylactery.
If it falters or fails in this task, its bones turn to dust until only its
skull remains. It contains only a fragment of the lich's malevolent life force
-- just enough so that if it is disturbed, these remains rise into the air
and assume a wraithlike form. The skull then emits a terrifying howl that can
slay the weak-hearted and leave others trembling with fear. Left alone, it
sinks back down and returns to the empty peace of its existence.
Few seek to become them, for it means an end to the existence they hoped to
preserve by becoming undead. However, time can erode its reason and memory,
causing it to retreat into its ancient tomb and forget to feed on souls.
The spells it once knew fade from its mind, and it no longer channels the
arcane energy it once wielded. However, even as a mere skull it remains a
deadly and vexing enemy.
It resembles a big, bipedal frog creature. Their skin is not entirely smooth,
and actually rather scaly. It has a big head with large maws, full of sharp
teeth.
One glance at a beholder is enough to assess its foul and otherworldly nature.
Aggressive, hateful, and greedy, these aberrations dismiss all other creatures
as lesser beings, toying with them or destroying them as they choose.
A beholder's spheroid body levitates at all times, and its great bulging eye
sits above a wide, toothy maw, while the smaller eyestalks that crown its body
twist and turn to keep its foes in sight. When a beholder sleeps, it closes
its central eye but leaves its smaller eyes open and alert.
This slaadi is the most evil of all slaadkind, bent on perpetuating
destruction.
Worshiped by the undead and by living creatures that channel the power of
undeath. A brooding and nihilistic entity, it yearns to make the multi
verse a place of death and darkness, forever unchanging except by his will.
A unique being with an appearance that reflects its particular evil nature,
it personifies tyranny with a totalitarian society dedicated to the
domination of mortal life. A servant to Asmodeus, it must continually expand
into the mortal realm to corrupt the souls from which new devils are spawned.
A demigod over all incarnations of the elements that make up the universe:
air, earth, fire, and water.
